title:
Behavioral Expectations in New Keynesian DSGE Models: Evidence from
  India's COVID-19 Recovery and Vaccination Program

sections.text:
#### Abstract

This paper extends the New Keynesian Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium (DSGE) framework by incorporating behavioral expectations to analyze India's output gap moments, focusing on COVID-19 and vaccination effects. Departing from rational expectations models, we show that behavioral expectations better capture the non-normal distribution of India's output gap. Using Hodrick-Prescott and Kalman filters, we estimate the output gap and match it with simulated moments. Following Dasgupta and Rajeev (2023), we model the pandemic as a prolonged negative demand shock and vaccinations as a positive supply shock, deriving the initial negative demand shock from observed output gap declines. We then identify the optimal positive supply shock that best aligns with the actual moments of the filtered output gap data. Using Euclidean distance minimization, we obtain initial supply shock magnitudes of 0.41 and 0.3 for the HP and Kalman filter specifications, respectively. Moreover, we quantitatively extend previous work by Dasgupta and Rajeev (2023), which presented only a simple Keynesian analysis.


Keywords: DSGE models, Behavioral expectations, COVID-19, Indian economy, Kalman filter, Hodrick-Prescott filter

JEL Classification: E12, E70, E71

[^0]
[^0]:    *Corresponding author. PhD Scholar, Department of Humanities and Social Sciences, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, Kharagpur, West Bengal, India. arpan.ms97@kgpian.iitkgp.ac.in, ORCID -$0000-0002-7777-5643$
    ${ }^{\dagger}$ Associate Professor, Department of Humanities and Social Sciences, Indian Institute of Technology Kharagpur, Kharagpur, West Bengal, India. siddhartha@hss.iitkgp.ac.in, ORCID - 0000-0001-8663-0246

# 1 Introduction 

The Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium (DSGE) model is a foundational tool in modern macroeconomics, widely employed to analyze business cycles in developed economies. However, its application to emerging economies, such as India, remains limited. Peiris, Saxegaard, and Anand (2010) made an early contribution by developing a DSGE model for India, incorporating macro-finance linkages and employing Bayesian estimation on data from 1996-2008 to examine macro-finance interactions.

Subsequent studies address specific objectives using DSGE models in the Indian context. Banerjee, Basu, and Ghate (2020) explored India's monetary policy transmission, emphasizing the weak aggregate demand channel. Sarkar (2020) investigated the relationship between the stock market and economic growth while assessing the economic impacts of COVID-19, highlighting the role of monetary transfers in reducing unemployment and enhancing output. Shah and Garg (2023) evaluated post-pandemic policy responses, finding that expansionary monetary policy influenced demand and supply, while fiscal policy effects were primarily demand driven. Sharma and Behera (2022) demonstrated the superiority of DSGE models over traditional methods, such as the Hodrick-Prescott (HP) filter, in analyzing output gaps during post-pandemic recovery. Sarkar (2022) developed a short-run general equilibrium model to understand the COVID-19 pandemic for India. Kumar (2023) examined productivity and monetary policy shocks, showing that productivity shocks foster economic growth, whereas monetary policy shocks have short-term effects on the output gap.

Despite these advancements, Dasgupta and Rajeev $(2020,2023)$ highlighted the scarcity of macro-theoretical work focused on India, particularly in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. They analyzed the pandemic using a simple Keynesian model, incorporating COVID-19-induced negative demand shocks and vaccination-driven positive supply shocks. However, their analysis remained graphical and did not adopt New Keynesian DSGE modeling.

Moreover, to the best of the authors' knowledge, no previous studies have implemented New Keynesian DSGE modeling in India using behavioral expectation formation. Existing literature has exclusively relied on rational expectations, which assumes agents are omniscient. While this approach has provided valuable insights, it may not adequately capture India's true output gap dynamics.

Our study makes the following distinct contributions to the existing literature. First, we show that the simple behavioral New Keynesian DSGE model matches the output gap moments better than the rational expectation DSGE model. Note that, for simplicity, we

take parameters from the existing literature.
Second, we extend this framework to analyze the economic impact of India's COVID19 vaccination program. We offer a more rigorous quantitative assessment based on Dasgupta and Rajeev's (2023) work, which provided a graphical analysis using a simple Keynesian model. We modeled the pandemic as a deterministic autoregressive negative demand shock, setting the magnitude of the initial shock equal to the observed output gap dip from the HP and Kalman filters. We find that our simulations closely match the actual moments of the output gap.

However, to obtain more accurate results, following Dasgupta and Rajeev (2023), we introduce vaccination-induced positive supply shock, and subsequently calibrate the deterministic autoregressive positive supply shock. Our findings indicate that initial shock values of 0.41 and 0.3 units correspond optimally to the estimated output gap moments derived from the HP and Kalman filters, respectively. This calibration employs a Euclidean distance-minimizing approach from the empirical moments, enabling precise replication of the statistical properties observed in the data. The methodology identifies optimal initial shock magnitudes that generate simulated skewness and kurtosis values closely approximating those derived from the filtration techniques, with minimal distances of 0.35 and 0.3 for the HP and Kalman filter specifications, respectively.

This research is particularly timely, given ongoing debates about policy responses to economic crises after the global pandemic. By demonstrating the superior fit of behavioral expectations in capturing Indian output gap dynamics, we provide policymakers with a more accurate framework for decision-making. Furthermore, our quantification of vaccination impacts offers valuable information for future integration of public health and economic policy.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows: Section 2 describes the data, Section 3 introduces the model, Section 4 depicts the results, and finally, Section 5 concludes.

# 2 Data 

The primary challenge faced by this paper lies in data collection, particularly for the output gap of the Indian economy. Unlike developed economies, real output gap data for India is not directly available and is typically estimated using various econometric techniques. This paper adopts a similar approach ${ }^{1}$. We obtain the Quarterly real GDP

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ Salunkhe and Patnaik (2019) adopted a similar approach to calculate the output gap of the Indian economy using the Hodrick Prescott filter.

data for the Indian economy from $\mathrm{FRED}^{2}$. Using this dataset ${ }^{3}$, we calculate the output gap using HP and Kalman filter.

We compare the moments of the output gap data with the simulated data from the 1000th to the 1080th observations of the simulated output gap.

# 3 The Model 

As described in the introduction, this paper uses the behavioral New Keynesian (NK) macroeconomic framework developed by De Grauwe and Ji (2019) in the context of the Indian economy. The Aggregate Demand (AD) equation is as follows:

$$
y_{t}=\widetilde{E}_{t}\left(y_{t+1}\right)-\frac{1}{\sigma}\left(i_{t}-\widetilde{E}_{t}\left(\pi_{t+1}\right)\right)+\varepsilon_{t} ; \quad t=1,2,3, \ldots
$$

where, $y_{t}$ denotes the output gap, $i_{t}$ is the short-term nominal interest rate, and

$$
\varepsilon_{t}=\rho_{\varepsilon} \varepsilon_{t-1}+\epsilon_{\varepsilon, t}
$$

where $\epsilon_{\varepsilon, t} \sim N(0,0.5)$ follows a normal distribution with mean zero and variance 0.5 , and $\rho_{\varepsilon}$ represents the autoregressive parameter of the AD shock (See; Kumar, 2023). The expectations in this model are non-rational.

The Phillips curve/AS equation, derived under monopolistic competition and Calvo pricing (Calvo, 1983), is as follows:

$$
\pi_{t}=\beta \widetilde{E}_{t}\left(\pi_{t+1}\right)+\kappa y_{t}+\eta_{t}
$$

where, $0 \leq \kappa \leq 1$ measures the sensitivity of inflation to the output gap, $\beta$ measures the discount rate, and $\pi_{t}$ is the inflation rate. Also, similar to the AD shock, we introduce,

$$
\eta_{t}=\rho_{\eta} \eta_{t-1}+\epsilon_{\eta, t}
$$

where $\epsilon_{\eta, t} \sim N(0,0.5)$ follows a normal distribution with mean zero and variance 0.5 , and $\rho_{\eta}$ represents the autoregressive parameter of the AS shock. Following De Grauwe and Ji (2020), the parameter $\kappa$ can be expressed as:

$$
\kappa=\frac{(1-\theta)(1-\beta \theta)}{\theta} \frac{\sigma(1-\varsigma)+\chi+\varsigma}{1-\varsigma+\varsigma \epsilon}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/NGDPRNSAXDCINQ
    ${ }^{3}$ The output gap data ranges from 1st quarter 2004 to the 1st quarter 2024.

where $1-\theta$ reflects the expected price of the Calvo lottery ticket, $\chi$ denotes the inverse Frisch elasticity of labor supply in the household utility function, $\varsigma$ represents the labor elasticity in the monopolistically competitive labor-augmented production function, $\left[Y_{t}^{i}=\right.$ $\left.A_{t} L_{t}^{1-\varsigma, i}\right]$, and $\dot{e}$ is the price elasticity of demand, which determines the markup price, $M$, for monopolistically competitive firms, $\left[M=\frac{\dot{e}}{\dot{e}-1}\right]$ (see Gali, 2008).

Note a $\theta$ fraction of firms cannot adjust prices in each period. For $\theta=1, b_{2}$ equals zero, indicating highly rigid prices, while for $\theta=0, b_{2}$ approaches infinity.

The short-term nominal interest rate $\left(i_{t}\right)$ is set according to the Taylor rule ${ }^{4}$ (Taylor, 1993; Blattner and Margaritov, 2010):

$$
i_{t}=\left(1-c_{3}\right)\left(c_{1} \pi_{t}+c_{2} y_{t}\right)+c_{3} i_{t-1}+u_{t}
$$

where the Taylor rule shock, $u_{t}$, follows the process:

$$
u_{t}=\rho_{u} u_{t-1}+\epsilon_{u, t}
$$

with $\epsilon_{u, t} \sim N(0,0.5)$ being a normally distributed error term with mean zero and variance $0.5, \rho_{u}$ representing the autoregressive parameter of the shock, and $c_{1}>1,0<c_{2}<1$ are the coefficients governing inflation and output gap responses, respectively. Note that the term $c_{3}$ captures interest rate smoothing.

# 3.1 Behavioral Expectation Formation 

Following De Grauwe and Ji (2019), the behavioral expectations model includes fundamentalist and extrapolator agents. The expectation of the output gap $\left(y_{t}\right)$ is as follows:

$$
\widetilde{E}_{t}\left(y_{t+1}\right)=\alpha_{f, t}^{y} \widetilde{E}_{t}^{f}\left(y_{t+1}\right)+\alpha_{e, t}^{y} \widetilde{E}_{t}^{e}\left(y_{t+1}\right)
$$

where fundamentalists expect $\widetilde{E}_{t}^{f}\left(y_{t+1}\right)=y_{s s},{ }^{5}$ and extrapolators use $\widetilde{E}_{t}^{e}\left(y_{t+1}\right)=y_{t-1}$, and $\alpha_{f, t}^{y}$ and $\alpha_{e, t}^{y}$ are the proportions based on the relative forecast performance (mean square forecast errors), which is as follows:

$$
U_{f, t}=-\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \varrho_{k}\left[y_{t-k-1}-\widetilde{E}_{f, t-k-2}\left(y_{t-k-1}\right)\right]^{2}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{4}$ While studies like Chattopadhyay (2013) incorporate a zero lower bound constraint in his monetary policy rule specifications, we abstain from this restriction given that India's policy rates have consistently remained above zero throughout our sample period of 2004-2024.
    ${ }^{5}$ which is normalized to zero.

$$
U_{e, t}=-\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \varrho_{k}\left[y_{t-k-1}-\widetilde{E}_{e, t-k-2}\left(y_{t-k-1}\right)\right]^{2}
$$

where $\varrho_{k}=(1-\rho) \rho^{k}$, with $0<\rho<1$ as the memory parameter. Hence, the proportion of fundamentalists become:

$$
\alpha_{f, t}^{y}=\frac{\exp \left(\gamma U_{f, t}\right)}{\exp \left(\gamma U_{f, t}\right)+\exp \left(\gamma U_{e, t}\right)}, \quad \alpha_{e, t}^{y}=1-\alpha_{f, t}^{y}
$$

where $\gamma$ is the willingness to learn/intensity of choice parameter; note that, using independent and identical expectation formation, we determine the simulated inflation rate.

We use the Binder and Pesaran (2000) technique and the Matlab code of De Grauwe (2012), to simulate our rational and behavioral expectation DSGE model.

# 3.2 Simulation Parameters 

Table 1 lists the simulation parameters, aligned with the papers described below:
Table 1: Simulation Parameters for the Indian Economy

![table_0](table_0)

It is important to note that this study does not have the calibrated values for the memory parameter and the willingness-to-learn parameter specific to the Indian economy. Therefore, for simplicity, this paper uses the parameters given by De Grauwe and Ji (2019). Additionally, unlike Kumar (2023), this paper incorporates aggregate supply (AS) shocks into the analysis.

|  | 2012) |

|  | Inverse of Frisch elasticity of labor supply (Anand and Prasad, 2010; |
| $\theta=0.75$ | Sharma and Behera, 2022) |

sections.text:
# 3.3 Estimation of the Output Gap 

To compute the output gap ${ }^{6}$, this paper employs two techniques: (i) the HodrickPrescott (HP) filter, and, (ii) Dynamic Linear Models based on the Kalman filter, where the output gap is as follows,

$$
\text { Output Gap }=\log (\text { Observed GDP })-\log (\text { Potential GDP })
$$

Please refer to the Appendix for more details on the HP and Kalman filter techniques.

## 4 Results
### 4.1 Behavioral Expectations vs Rational Expectations: Analysis of Output Gap Moments in India

Table 2 compares the statistical moments of the simulated output gap data under rational and behavioral expectations with the actual Indian output gap data ${ }^{7}$. We find

Table 2: Comparison of Moments for Expectation Formation Models and Real Data

![table_1](table_1)

that the actual output gap data, derived using both the Kalman filter and the HP filter, reveal significant non-normality characterized by negative skewness and high kurtosis. Specifically, the Kalman output gap exhibits a skewness of -1.48 and kurtosis of 9.12 ,

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{6}$ See, Goyel and Arora (2016) for a similar analysis using the HP and Kalman filter to estimate the potential GDP of India.
    ${ }^{7}$ we apply identical shocks to both models.

while the HP output gap closely mirrors these values with a skewness of -1.45 and kurtosis of 9.32. In contrast, the simulated behavioral expectations, with a skewness of -0.23 and kurtosis of 1.58 , align more closely with the actual output gap data than the rational expectations model. The latter generates highly unrealistic moments, including a positive skewness of 0.56 and a kurtosis of 2.90 , suggesting that rational expectations fail to replicate the complex patterns observed in actual output gap data.

To further assess the statistical moments of these models, we perform normality tests such as the Jarque-Bera (JB) test. The results show that the actual Kalman and HP output gaps are definitively non-normal, as evidenced by p-values less than 0.001 . The behavioral expectations model exhibits non-normality, with a p-value less than 0.05 . On the other hand, the rational expectations model produces normal output gap data with a p-value greater than 0.05 , underscoring its limitations in capturing the non-normality of the output gap data for India.

From the above analysis, it is evident that behavioral expectations outperform rational expectations in representing India's output gap. This replicates the seminal work of De Grauwe (2012) for the US economy.

tables.table_1:
| Data Type | Skewness | Kurtosis | Normality (5\%) | p-value |
| :-- | :--: | :--: | :--: | :--: |
| Simulated Behavioral | -0.23 | 1.58 | Non-Normal | 0.03 |
| Actual Output Gap (Kalman) | -1.48 | 9.12 | Non-Normal | $<0.001$ |
| Simulated Rational | 0.56 | 2.90 | Normal | 0.08 |
| Actual Output Gap (HP) | -1.45 | 9.32 | Non-Normal | $<0.001$ |

sections.text:
# 4.2 Likelihood Ratio Test for Structural Break in Output Gap 

Having established the superiority of behavioral expectations in modeling India's output gap, we extend our analysis to examine potential structural breaks in the data surrounding the COVID-19 period. Our investigation pursues three distinct objectives. First, we test for structural breaks in India's output gap data across the pre and post-COVID periods. Second, we evaluate whether the behavioral NKDSGE model is able to match statistical moments in the post-COVID era. Third, we quantitatively assess the Dasgupta and Rajeev (2023) framework, which conceptualizes the pandemic's impact through simultaneous aggregate demand and aggregate supply shocks in an aggregate demand-aggregate supply (AD-AS) model.

To check for the structural break, we plot the series of output gap data below. Figure 1 reveals a visible structural break in Q1 2020. To formally validate this observation, we employ a Likelihood Ratio (LR) test to examine the presence of a structural break in the Output Gap series, estimated using both Kalman and HP filters. The test evaluates two nested models:

- Model 1 (Null Hypothesis): Assumes no structural break and fits a constant

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: Quarterly Output Gap of India: Comparison of HP and Kalman Filter
mean model:

$$
Y_{t}=\mu+\epsilon_{t}
$$

where $Y_{t}$ is the observed output gap, $\mu$ is the constant mean, and $\epsilon_{t}$ represents the error term.

- Model 2 (Alternative Hypothesis): Incorporates a structural break at Q1 2020, dividing the dataset into pre- and post-break periods:

$$
Y_{t}=\mu_{1} I(t \leq \mathrm{Q} 12020)+\mu_{2} I(t>\mathrm{Q} 12020)+\epsilon_{t}
$$

where $\mu_{1}$ and $\mu_{2}$ represent the means for the pre and post-break periods, respectively, and $I$ is an indicator function.

The Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) results for the HP and Kalman filters are presented below.

Table 3: ANOVA Table for Likelihood Ratio Test (HP Filter).

![table_2](table_2)

Tables 3 and 4 present the Likelihood Ratio test results for the HP and Kalman filterderived output gap series, respectively. For the HP-filtered series (Table 3), Model 2,

which incorporates a Q1 2020 structural break, demonstrates superior fit with a reduced Residual Sum of Squares (RSS) of 0.21 compared to Model 1's RSS of 0.24 . The associated F-statistic of 11.52 confirms the statistical significance of this structural break.

Table 4: ANOVA Table for Likelihood Ratio Test (Kalman Filter).

![table_3](table_3)

The Kalman-filtered series (Table 4) exhibits even stronger evidence of a structural break. The RSS decreases substantially from 0.13 in Model 1 to 0.09 in Model 2, yielding a higher F-statistic of 28.41. Both filtering methodologies thus provide robust empirical support for a structural break in India's output gap at Q1 2020.

| :-- | :--: | :--: |
| Residual Degrees of Freedom (Df) | 80 | 79 |
| Residual Sum of Squares (RSS) | 0.24 | 0.21 |
| Degrees of Freedom (Df) | - | 1 |
| Sum of Squares (SS) | - | 0.03 |
| F-statistic | - | 11.52 |
| p-value $(\operatorname{Pr}(>F))$ | - | 0.001 |

| :-- | :--: | :--: |

sections.text:
# 4.3 Behavioral Expectation and COVID-19 Policy Analysis for India 

Building upon our findings of behavioral expectations' superior performance and the confirmed Q1 2020 structural break in India's output gap, we now analyze COVID-19related policy implications.

We initialize the model with zero shocks across all variables and then introduce a demand shock that spans ten quarters (period 999-1008) to replicate the economic impact of COVID-19 from Q1 2020 to Q2 2023. The initial shock magnitude is calibrated to -0.27 , matching the observed HP-filtered output gap data. We modeled the shock's temporal decay using a persistence parameter of 0.9 , capturing the gradual economic recovery. The shock structure can be expressed as:

$$
\epsilon_{t}= \begin{cases}-0.27, & \text { if } t=999 \\ \epsilon_{t-1} \cdot 0.9, & \text { if } 999<t \leq 1008\end{cases}
$$

where $\epsilon_{t}$ represents the demand shock applied to the AD equation.
The simulated model generates statistical moments that closely approximate the empirical post-COVID data. Using the HP filter-calibrated shock (-0.27), the simulated output gap for the sixteen quarters following COVID-19 ( $\mathrm{t}=1000$ to $\mathrm{t}=1015$ ) produces

a skewness of -0.26 and kurtosis of 1.51 , closely matching the actual post-COVID values of -0.16 and 2.57 , respectively.

To verify robustness, we recalibrate the model using the Kalman filter-derived initial shock (-0.18). This specification generates comparable moments (skewness: -0.28 , kurtosis: 1.55) that align with the actual Kalman-filtered output gap characteristics (skewness: -0.41 , kurtosis: 2.39 ).

Next, following Dasgupta and Rajeev (2023), we introduce a positive supply shock in period 1003 to period 1008 ( 6 quarters) to mimic the economic impact of vaccinations during the COVID-19 pandemic ${ }^{8}$. The initial value of this shock is set to constant2, simulated for India. This shock decays over subsequent periods at a rate of 0.9 , representing the gradual reduction of the influence of the supply shock ${ }^{9}$. Mathematically,

$$
\eta_{t}= \begin{cases}\text { constant } 2, & \text { if } t=1003 \\ \eta_{t-1} \cdot 0.9, & \text { if } 1003<t \leq 1008\end{cases}
$$

where $\eta_{t}$ represents the supply shock applied to the AS equation.
Next, we conduct a grid search over the initial magnitude of the positive supply shock (constant2), ranging from 10 to 0 in increments of 0.01 , and perform 2000 simulations per grid point, which amounts to a total of 2,000,000 simulations. We then analyze the skewness and kurtosis of the truncated output gap ${ }^{10}$ over this grid for 16 quarters, aligning with the 16 post-COVID quarters observed in the data.

To determine the optimal supply shock magnitude that best matches the empirical moments, we employ Euclidean distance minimization, where the distance metric is as follows.

$$
d=\sqrt{\left(\text { skewness }_{\text {sim }}-\text { skewness }_{\text {data }}\right)^{2}+\left(\text { kurtosis }_{\text {sim }}-\text { kurtosis }_{\text {data }}\right)^{2}}
$$

We find that an initial positive supply shock of 0.41 best replicates the empirical skewness and kurtosis of $(-0.16,2.57)$ obtained from the HP filter, with the simulated moments yielding $(-0.06,2.23)$ at the minimum Euclidean distance of 0.35 .

Similarly, repeating the same procedure for the Kalman filter-generated output gap, where the empirical moments are $(-0.41,2.39)$, we find that the optimal initial supply

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{8}$ Vaccines were first available in India in Q1 2021, and we assume that vaccines were in operation to eliminate the crisis from Q1 2021 to Q2 2022, or 6 quarters. Hence, we apply the positive supply shock only to 6 quarters.
    ${ }^{9}$ For simplicity, we assume both the aggregate demand and the supply shocks decay at the same rate.
    ${ }^{10}$ Note, the simulated output gap grid is defined over the range $t=1000$ to $t=1015$.

shock magnitude is 0.3 . The simulated moments for this case are $(-0.38,2.09)$, with a minimized Euclidean distance of 0.3 .

By analyzing these additional results using Euclidean distance minimization, we further confirm the robustness of our model and methodology. This reinforces the validity of our approach to model negative aggregate demand and positive aggregate supply shocks within the simple NKDSGE framework. Moreover, our model quantitatively extends the existing research gap present in the papers of Dasgupta and Rajeev (2020, 2023), where the analysis was graphical.

# 5 Conclusion 

This study contributes to the growing body of literature on macroeconomic modeling for emerging economies by introducing behavioral expectations into a New Keynesian DSGE framework tailored for India. By moving beyond the conventional reliance on rational expectations, we demonstrate that behavioral expectations better capture the moments of India's output gap data, particularly in the context of COVID-19-induced economic disruptions.

Our quantitative analysis extends previous work by Dasgupta and Rajeev (2023), providing a more rigorous evaluation of the economic impact of India's vaccination program. By modeling the pandemic as a deterministic autoregressive negative demand shock and calibrating the corresponding positive supply shocks, we chose simulated output gap moments to match the moments of the output gap derived from HP and Kalman filters. The results underscore the utility of incorporating behavioral expectations in macroeconomic models to better reflect real-world dynamics.

These findings are particularly relevant for the formation of policy responses to economic crises. The superior performance of the behavioral New Keynesian DSGE model offers policymakers a more accurate and realistic framework. Furthermore, our quantification of vaccination-driven supply shocks provides actionable insights for integrating public health initiatives with economic recovery strategies, contributing to more effective policy design in future crises.

[15] Goyal, A., and Arora, S. (2016), Estimating the Indian natural interest rate: A semi-structural approach, Economic Modelling, 58, 141-153. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.econmod.2016.05.023
[16] Kumar, A. (2023), A basic two-sector new keynesian dsge model of the indian economy, Theoretical and Practical Research in the Economic Fields, 14(1), 36. https://doi.org/10.14505/tpref.v14.1(27).04
[17] Peiris, S., Saxegaard, M., and Anand, R. (2010), An estimated model with macrofinancial linkages for India, IMF Working Paper, 10(21), 1. https://doi.org/10.5089/9781451962321.001
[18] Salunkhe, B., and Patnaik, A. (2019), Inflation dynamics and monetary policy in India: A New Keynesian Phillips Curve perspective, South Asian Journal of Macroeconomics and Public Finance, 8(2), 144-179. https://doi.org/10.1177/2277978719861186.
[19] Sarkar, A. (2020), Understanding the short-run relationship between stock market and growth in emerging economies, Journal of Quantitative Economics, 18(2). https://doi.org/10.1007/s40953-019-00183-x.
[20] Sarkar, A. (2022), Understanding the COVID economic crisis: A short-run general equilibrium framework, South Asian Journal of Macroeconomics and Public Finance, 11(2), 217-245. https://doi.org/10.1177/22779787221097787.
[21] Shah, S. A., and Garg, B. (2023), Testing policy effectiveness during COVID-19: An NK-DSGE analysis, Journal of Asian Economics, 84, 101577. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.asieco.2022.101577.

[22] Sharma, S., and Behera, H. (2022), A dissection of Indian growth using a DSGE filter, Journal of Asian Economics, 80, 101480. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.asieco.2022.101480.
[23] Taylor, J. B. (1993), Discretion versus policy rules in practice, Carnegie-Rochester Conference Series on Public Policy, 39, 195-214. https://doi.org/10.1016/0167-2231(93)90009-L

# 6 Appendix
### 6.1 Hodrick-Prescott Filter

The Hodrick-Prescott filter minimizes an objective function to decompose logarithm of real GDP $\left(z_{t}\right)$ into its trend component $\left(t_{t}\right)$ and cyclical component. The filter actively balances two competing goals: fitting the observed GDP as closely as possible and ensuring the smoothness of the trend. The objective function is as follows:

$$
\min \sum_{t=1}^{n}\left(z_{t}-t_{t}\right)^{2}+\lambda \sum_{t=2}^{n-1}\left[\left(z_{t+1}-t_{t}\right)-\left(t_{t}-t_{t-1}\right)\right]^{2}
$$

where the first term measures the goodness of fit by minimizing the deviations of the log real GDP $\left(z_{t}\right)$ from the trend $\left(t_{t}\right)$, and the second term penalizes changes in the growth rate of the trend to ensure smoothness. This paper sets $\lambda=1600$, as we have quarterly data.

### 6.2 Kalman Filter

Dynamic linear models often consist of two main equations: the measurement equation and the state evolution equation. The measurement equation relates the logarithm of observable GDP $\left(z_{t}\right)$ to the unobservable state variables $\left(\mathbf{s}_{t}\right)$, which include the logarithm of potential GDP $\left(s_{1 t}\right)$ and the trend growth rate $\left(s_{2 t}\right)$ :

$$
z_{t}=\mathbf{F} \mathbf{s}_{t}+\nu_{t}
$$

where,

$$
\mathbf{F}=[1,1]
$$

$$
\mathbf{s}_{t}=\left[\begin{array}{l}
s_{1 t} \\
s_{2 t}
\end{array}\right]
$$

and $\nu_{t} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, V)$ is the measurement noise with variance $V=0.06^{2}$.
The state evolution equation describes how the state variables evolve over time:

$$
\mathbf{s}_{t+1}=\mathbf{G} \mathbf{s}_{t}+\omega_{t}
$$

where,

$$
\mathbf{G}=\left[\begin{array}{ll}
1 & 0 \\
1 & 1
\end{array}\right]
$$

and $\omega_{t} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \mathbf{W})$ represents the process noise with covariance matrix:

$$
\mathbf{W}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
0.06^{2} & 0 \\
0 & 0.06^{2}
\end{array}\right]
$$

Note, the model starts with an initial guess for the state variables,

$$
\mathbf{s}_{0}=\left[\begin{array}{c}
\log (\text { Observed GDP at } t=1) \\
0
\end{array}\right]
$$

and assumes an initial covariance matrix (See; Goyel and Arora, 2016)

$$
\mathbf{C}_{0}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
0.06^{2} & 0 \\
0 & 0.06^{2}
\end{array}\right]
$$

The model then uses the Kalman filter to estimate the parameters and states recursively. The filter alternates between the following steps:

Prediction Step Predict the state and its covariance for time $t+1$ :

$$
\begin{gathered}
\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{t+1 \mid t}=\mathbf{G} \hat{\mathbf{s}}_{t \mid t} \\
\mathbf{P}_{t+1 \mid t}=\mathbf{G} \mathbf{P}_{t \mid t} \mathbf{G}^{\top}+\mathbf{W}
\end{gathered}
$$

where $\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{t+1 \mid t}$ represents the predicted state and $\mathbf{P}_{t+1 \mid t}$ represents its covariance.

Update Step Kalman filter incorporates new observations to refine the state estimate:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathbf{K}_{t}=\mathbf{P}_{t+1 \mid t} \mathbf{F}^{\top}\left(\mathbf{F} \mathbf{P}_{t+1 \mid t} \mathbf{F}^{\top}+V\right)^{-1} \\
\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{t+1 \mid t+1}=\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{t+1 \mid t}+\mathbf{K}_{t}\left(z_{t+1}-\mathbf{F} \hat{\mathbf{s}}_{t+1 \mid t}\right) \\
\mathbf{P}_{t+1 \mid t+1}=\left(\mathbf{I}-\mathbf{K}_{t} \mathbf{F}\right) \mathbf{P}_{t+1 \mid t}
\end{gathered}
$$

Here, $\mathbf{K}_{t}$ represents the Kalman gain, $\hat{\mathbf{s}}_{t+1 \mid t+1}$ represents the updated state estimate, and $\mathbf{P}_{t+1 \mid t+1}$ represents its covariance.

Finally we obtain the output gap $\left(y_{t}\right)$ using ${ }^{11}$ :

$$
\text { Output } \operatorname{Gap}_{t}=\left(z_{t}\right)-\left(s_{1 t}\right)
$$

where $z_{t}$ represents the logarithm of observed GDP and $s_{1 t}$ represents the estimated logarithm of potential GDP at time $t$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{11}$ The R code will be made available on request. Please note that this code truncates the first observation of the estimated logarithm of potential GDP as the first two estimates become identical.

abstract:
This paper extends the New Keynesian Dynamic Stochastic General Equilibrium
(DSGE) framework by incorporating behavioral expectations to analyze India's
output gap moments, focusing on COVID-19 and vaccination effects. Departing
from rational expectations models, we show that behavioral expectations better
capture the non-normal distribution of India's output gap. Using
Hodrick-Prescott and Kalman filters, we estimate the output gap and match it
with simulated moments. Following Dasgupta and Rajeev (2023), we model the
pandemic as a prolonged negative demand shock and vaccinations as a positive
supply shock, deriving the initial negative demand shock from observed output
gap declines. We then identify the optimal positive supply shock that best
aligns with the actual moments of the filtered output gap data. Using Euclidean
distance minimization, we obtain initial supply shock magnitudes of 0.41 and
0.3 for the HP and Kalman filter specifications, respectively. Moreover, we
quantitatively extend previous work by Dasgupta and Rajeev (2023), which
presented only a simple Keynesian analysis.
